confession.devil_appearance: appeared as a stranger; rode a black horse
confession.seduction_context: After losing money on a diseased horse at St. Dié fair - only received 2 francs when he had paid 24. Seduced by 'malin esprit' on way back from St. Nicolas fair, gave himself to the stranger and received money which disappeared. Met master again 6-7 years later when going to see sister accused at St. Clement, was given illusory money to buy her release. On return journey met Mre Parsin again and renounced God.
powder_types: powder given by master to cause animal deaths and illness
sabbat_locations: fontaine St. Martin proche de Gondrexon
sabbat_activities: banqueting with boiled meat and wine (not very good)
making hail by beating water of fountain and stream with rods
class division - rich/gentlemen more favored than poor
rich wanted to damage wheat, poor opposed and preferred oats be damaged instead, but rich prevailed
beating water with red wood rods to create storm clouds and hail
running through woods breaking acorns from oak trees to destroy mast
creating whirlwind by uprooting oak trees (as it seemed to him)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Raimbault's son Noel borrowed a horse and blinded it in one eye. Went to house to complain, had violent dispute with Raimbault's wife and smacked her face. Sharp words followed with accused.
testimony.threat_quote: il s'en donroit bien tost de garde / un cher coup

testimony.quarrel_subject: Had hired Raimbault's daughter Barbelline as servant. At end of service at St. Martin, accused asked him to buy her new shoes. Refusal led to quarrel and Raimbault struck him but denied it in street when witness called bystanders to witness.
testimony.threat_quote: que se seroient chers souliers pour luy et qu'il les payeroit bien cher

testimony.quarrel_subject: Suspected accused of stealing pears, led to court case
Accused wanted him to hire one of his sons as servant, but witness refused and hired someone else when he passed witness and wife returning from reaping

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: shortly afterwards - while collecting 'lin' and eating bread, suddenly lost appetite as he passed place where they had encountered accused

testimony.quarrel_subject: Raimbault's son (in service of Vaultrin) let master's horses stray into oats of her father Didier Hachon. Father sought reparation, accused said he would pay rather than Vaultrin but failed to do so.

Multiple incidents: (1) Raimbault lost keeping of 'bestes a cornes' to Waltin of Blesmerey when witness's father-in-law Jean Quirien was 'Imballe'. Called Raimbault to heal ill cow - failed, though he cured another cow belonging to brother-in-law. (2) Witness's brother Claudon was hired by curé to thresh - Raimbault angry because he previously did this.

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after ousting accused from keeping troupeau
after ousting accused from keeping troupeau

testimony.quarrel_subject: Soldiers billeted on village broke witness's oven. Raimbault offered pots from his own oven to remake it, on understanding witness would return service. 3-4 years later accused asked for 5 dozen pots when he had only provided 18. Refusal followed by quarrel.
Repeated husband's story of quarrel over provision of shoes for accused's daughter
Had quarreled with him 9 years before
He and his daughter quarreled with Raimbault 2 years ago
While in fields, beat Raimbault's daughter Barbelline. Her father came and struck him on head with an 'escourge'

Lent horses unwillingly to Raimbault for carting jobs on two occasions (9 years and 6 years before). Lost fine cow from communal herd of which accused was paistre - believed in revenge for his wife's failure to continue habitual gifts of lard, meat, and other items given 'more from fear than friendship'
Retold story of straying horses from daughter (witness 5)
Dispute over damage caused by horses

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: day after accused passed close by it

testimony.quarrel_subject: Incident of brother breaking leg after dispute over threshing for curé

timeline.subject: Nicolas Raimbault
timeline.details: Said he was about 50, native of Reillon. Generally agreed circumstantial details or said he couldn't remember. Admitted stealing 4 sheaves of wheat.

timeline.subject: Nicolas Raimbault
timeline.details: Confronted with witnesses. No reproach against any witnesses but denied harming any person or animal and making threats. Began to grieve without shedding tears - reproached that this was 'sign of a sorcerer'

timeline.subject: Nicolas Raimbault
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asked for ordinary and extraordinary torture

timeline.subject: Nicolas Raimbault
timeline.details: Made difficulty renouncing Devil. Resisted thumbscrews and rack - confessed nothing. Next day given tourtillons and strappado with 50 pound weight attached to legs. Despite torture remained obstinate in denials.

timeline.subject: Nicolas Raimbault
timeline.details: Voluntary confession - declared 'estoit sorcier et content de mourir'

timeline.subject: Nicolas Raimbault
timeline.details: Confirmation of confessions. Asked judges to forgive him for troubling them.

timeline.subject: Nicolas Raimbault
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asked for death sentence

timeline.subject: Nicolas Raimbault
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approved death sentence

torture.restrictions: none - judges decided strappado with weight was reasonable given his pertinacity and strength

accomplices_named.name: Claudon de Benaumesnil
accomplices_named.context: Named under torture as accomplice at sabbat. Later withdrew accusation, saying he only made it from fear of torture and because this person had 'bad reputation'. Persisted in discharging him even when attached to stake.

accomplices_named.name: Claude Marchal
accomplices_named.context: Named under torture as accomplice at sabbat, recognized by bearing since everyone wore masks (green, yellow, or red). Later withdrew accusation, saying he only made it from fear of torture and because this person had 'bad reputation'. Persisted in discharging them when attached to stake.

accomplices_named.name: Margueritte Francois
accomplices_named.context: Was brought in during torture to repeat her accusation that she had seen Nicolas Raimbault at Sabbat

prior_accusations.context: Maire Claude Dieudegnon testified that 2-3 years before he heard Raimbault's sister had been executed at St. Clement and had accused him
Witness 8 (Chrestienne) testified that 18 years before her late aunt Claudatte told her the accused was a witch - believed this more because Claudatte was herself suspected

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Raimbault to Dieudegnon Claude
notable_quotes.french: un cher coup / il s'en donroit bien tost de garde
notable_quotes.english: it would be a dear blow / he would soon take care of it
notable_quotes.context: Threat after quarrel over blinded horse

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Raimbault to Jean Dieudenon
notable_quotes.french: que se seroient chers souliers pour luy et qu'il les payeroit bien cher
notable_quotes.english: that they would be expensive shoes for him and that he would pay dearly for them
notable_quotes.context: Threat after refusal to buy shoes for accused's daughter

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Raimbault to witness's brother
notable_quotes.english: that he was taking away his bread
notable_quotes.context: Angry that brother was hired to thresh for curé instead of him

notable_quotes.speaker: Chrestienne femme a Nicolas Hachon
notable_quotes.french: cy donna telle apprehension qu'elle craindoit tousjours ledit prevenu, et taschoit de l'entretenir et ne le point fascher craindant d'en recevoir incommodité
notable_quotes.english: this gave her such apprehension that she always feared the accused, and tried to maintain good relations and not anger him, fearing to receive harm from him
notable_quotes.context: After being told accused was a witch by her aunt

notable_quotes.speaker: Claude Dieudegnon maire
notable_quotes.french: plus par crainte que par amytié
notable_quotes.english: more from fear than from friendship
notable_quotes.context: Describing his wife's habitual gifts of lard, meat, and other items to accused

notable_quotes.speaker: Claude Dieudegnon maire
notable_quotes.french: lors desdits desastres il ne pensoit poinct audit prevenu, que depuis qu'il a entendu sa mauvaise renommée qui la mis en ceste oppinion
notable_quotes.english: at the time of these disasters he didn't think of the accused, but since he heard of his bad reputation it put him in this opinion
notable_quotes.context: Explaining how hearing reputation changed his interpretation of past losses

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudon Crolbesnier
notable_quotes.french: et ne scavoit sy cela procedoit de son sortilege, ou bien pour les demerites dudit depposant
notable_quotes.english: and didn't know if this proceeded from his sorcery, or from the witness's own demerits
notable_quotes.context: Uncertain whether loss of cow was witchcraft or divine punishment

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Raimbault at torture
notable_quotes.french: que le diable emporte le diable, et que le diable puisse cheoire sur les sorciers et sorcieres
notable_quotes.english: may the devil take the devil, and may the devil fall upon sorcerers and witches
notable_quotes.context: Reluctant renunciation of devil when asked by executioner

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Raimbault
notable_quotes.french: estoit sorcier et content de mourir
notable_quotes.english: was a sorcerer and content to die

notable_quotes.speaker: Judges to Nicolas Raimbault
notable_quotes.french: joinct la mauvaise mine qu'il porte et ses yeulx fort enfoncé dans la teste avec ung hideux regard
notable_quotes.english: joined to the bad appearance he bears and his eyes deeply sunken in his head with a hideous look
notable_quotes.context: Judges listing evidence against him during torture

notable_quotes.speaker: Master at sabbat
notable_quotes.context: Devil's command during sabbat activity of uprooting oak trees

his sister had been executed at St. Clement
he and his daughter quarrelled with Raimbaut
when serving Claudon de Vauernot at Reillon
come to live with brother in Reillon (witness 6)

economic_context.details: Multiple economic tensions: (1) Lost position keeping 'bestes a cornes' to Waltin of Blesmerey. (2) Lost threshing job for curé to another. (3) Dispute over reciprocal service - provided 18 pots but asked for 5 dozen in return. (4) Poverty mentioned as motivation for seduction - lost 22 francs on diseased horse. (5) Theft of wood from curé's garden admitted due to poverty. (6) Theft of 4 sheaves of wheat admitted. (7) Called in as animal healer - occupation as expert. (8) Served as paistre (herdsman) for communal herd. (9) Mayor's wife gave gifts 'more from fear than friendship' - lard, meat, other items. (10) Class tensions at sabbat - rich/gentlemen more favored than poor.

extraction_metadata.notes: Exceptionally detailed trial with 18 witnesses, extensive torture documentation, vivid sabbat confessions including class tensions (rich vs. poor), and detailed maleficia catalog. Notable features: (1) Accused resisted extensive torture before voluntary confession. (2) Confession includes rich narrative detail about sabbats with social hierarchy. (3) Named accomplices later exonerated - accused withdrew accusations. (4) Joint trial with Margueritte Francois who accused him. (5) Sister previously executed and had accused him. (6) Economic tensions prominent - lost jobs, reciprocal service disputes, poverty as motivation. (7) Pattern of animal deaths (especially horses) following quarrels. (8) Reputation ranging from 3-20 years among witnesses. (9) No tears during confrontation noted as 'sign of sorcerer'. (10) Detailed confession of weather magic and crop damage. Costs: 55 francs for preliminary enquiries (joint with Margueritte Francois).
